John Backus

General

John Backus was born in 1924 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Backus was the inventor of Fortan and in 1977 he received the Turing Award for his use of high-level programming in Fortan. Additionally he invented the Backus-Naur form, a notation of formal language syntax.

Contributions

John Backus struggled with his studies in high school and even more at university where he attended in Virginia and studied Chemistry. After that he was enlisted in the army and served in WW2. His performance at the army tests were exceptional and thus he was sent by the army to study engineering at the University of Pittsburgh.
Backus continued to study medicine but inevitably quit. During that time John Backus was diagnosed with a cranial bone tumor which was successfully removed. His medical studies allowed him to design a plate to substitute the one that was placed on his head after the tumor removal operation. For this achievement Backus received an honorable medical discharge from the U.S. Army in 1946.
In 1949 he graduated from Columbia University with a degree in Mathematics and one year later with a master degree in Mathematics as well.
In 1950 Backus joined IBM and started working on a program that would calculate positions of the moon.
In 1953 Backus created a high-level programming language for IBM called Speedcoding. It supported software for the IBM 701. John Backus was very involved in the creation of ALGOL 58 and later ALGOL 60. He developed the Backus-naur form (BNF) which was the global notation used for grammar-free and context-free programming language. This contributed heavily in the creation of compilers. The BNF also contributed to the Turing Award. His next project was developing functional-programming (FP) as a way to deviate from the Von Neumann programming style. Nevertheless it was not received well, as people viewed it like traditional functional programming.
Backus later developed the successor of FP, FL (Function Level) which was an IBM project involving members from all over the world. FL stayed inside IBM and stopped development after the project was complete. Documents were not made public as FL was not fully compatible with functional programming languages of the time.
John Backus died in 2007 at the age of 82 in Oregon.
